docs.lead_paragraph: THEY came out of the polling place at the Camden Street School in Newark's Central Ward around 11:30 in the morning, Cynthia Desouza taking small steps in her walker, her 18-year-old daughter, Stacey, bounding out toward their car. ''Congratulations,'' Mrs. Desouza, 53, said jauntily, the painful steps almost forgotten for a moment. ''Congratulations. Your first vote. You should be proud.''
docs.abstract: Peter Abblebome Our Towns column discusses strong Democratic voter turnout in Newark (NJ) (M)
docs.snippet: In this election year on steroids, every vote in the traditionally Democratic city of Newark felt like a personal statement.

docs.lead_paragraph: Humana, the biggest manager of health plans for the United States military, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 36 percent on higher revenue from Medicare and medical cost controls. The company raised its 2004 profit forecast. Net income increased to $84.3 million, or 52 cents a share, from $62.1 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier, the company said. A survey of 14 analysts by Thomson Financial produced an average forecast of 44 cents a share.
docs.abstract: Humana, health plan manager, reports third-quarter net income rose 36 percent, to $84.3 million, up from $62.1 million in 2003 period; revenue rose 2 percent (S)
docs.snippet: Humana, the biggest manager of health plans for the U.S., said that third-quarter profit rose 36 percent on higher revenue from Medicare and medical cost controls.

docs.lead_paragraph: Leann Harrington's experience losing her job has an all-too-familiar ring, one that is soon likely to be heard with even greater frequency. The textile plant where she was employed shut down last year, a victim of fierce foreign competition. After scrambling, she was lucky to land a job as manager and waitress at the Towel City Junction Cafe, earning $3 an hour plus tips, a fraction of her factory wages.

headline.main: Textile Quotas to End Soon, Punishing Carolina Mill Towns

docs.abstract: First article in periodic series Made Elsewhere, on global clothing business, focuses on plant closings and job losses in Carolinas, which drew mills decades ago with prospect of inexpensive nonunion labor; industry is now migrating abroad in search of ever-cheaper labor; gradual shift is poised to turn into rout after Jan 1, when World Trade Organization is set to end global system of country-by-country quotas regulating international trade in textiles and apparel; change also threatens poorest developing nations unable to compete with China; politicians from both parties in Southeast are wringing last-minute concessions from White House that could slow flood of imports from China; most experts expect that China, if left unimpeded, will gain almost half global apparel market; map; graph of China's share of exports; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With the global quota system for the textile industry coming to an end in 2005, the gradual loss of textile and clothing factories in the Carolinas may turn into a rout.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the beginning, they laughed at Arthur E. Imperatore Sr., labeled his dream a folly and ridiculed his plan to restore ferry service to New York's waterways as little more than a romantic vision and a throwback to a bygone age. Then came Sept. 11, 2001. Suddenly ferry travel became more than a lure to attract buyers to luxury developments or a way to keep a few cars off the road and a few people off crowded trains and buses. It became a necessity in a regional transportation system that was wounded and more vulnerable than many had thought.

headline.main: Once Folly, Then Vital Post-9/11 Link, Ferry Seeks Help

docs.abstract: New York Waterway owner Arthur E Imperatore Sr meets with Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and Transportation Department (NYC) for help with routes and financing; service, once considered quaint, family-owned ferry, became vitally important after Sept 11 terrorist attacks, but is once again in financial distress; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A ferry company that gained popularity following Sept. 11, 2001, is facing financial problems and has turned to regional transportation officials for help.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PORT AUTHORITY OF NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY

docs.lead_paragraph: In the national debate over what to do about the growing number of working people with little or no health insurance, no other company may be taking more heat than the country's largest employer, Wal-Mart Stores. The company, despite its popularity with consumers, has grown accustomed to being accused of crushing Main Street merchants with its sprawling stores and low prices and of driving down wages for workers across the retail industry. And more than a million former and current female Wal-Mart employees are part of a sex discrimination lawsuit that the company is fighting.

headline.main: States Are Battling Against Wal-Mart Over Health Care

docs.abstract: Critics say Wal-Mart's miserly approach to employee health care is forcing many of its workers and their families into state insurance programs or making them rely on charity care by hospitals; survey by Georgia officials finds more than 10,000 children of Wal-Mart employees are in state's health program for children at annual cost of nearly $10 million to taxpayers; efforts are under way in California, Washington State and elsewhere to adopt measures that would force big employers like Wal-Mart to either provide affordable health insurance to workers or pay into state insurance pool; Wal-Mart claims it offers health coverage to 58 percen of employees who are eligible; this compares with insured rate of 96 percent of eligible employees of Costco Wholesale, Wal-Mart's closest competitor nationwide; critics say many Wal-Mart workers are unable to meet eligibility requirements or cannot afford monthly premiums as high as $264 a month for family of $8-per-hour cashier; Wal-Mart benefits executive Susan Chambers says larger issue of whether companies can and should absorb soaring cost of health care is national issue; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Wal-Mart is under attack for what critics see as a miserly approach to employee health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The presidential campaign was coming to a close in an epic cacophony of advertisements striking notes of hope and fear, patriotism and betrayal as the candidates headed Sunday into a two-day sprint to sway an electorate that remained stubbornly deadlocked. Shuttling in opposite directions across Ohio and here in Florida, Senator John Kerry and President Bush hopped from church services to outdoor rallies, delivering variations of their messages in an effort to galvanize supporters -- and, perhaps, to win over those last few undecided voters.

headline.main: Frantic Presidential Race Ends With a Flood of Ads

docs.abstract: Presidential campaign is culminating with flood of advertisements striking notes of hope and fear, patriotism and betrayal; record advertising war will total estimated $60 million in final week, fully one-quarter of all advertising spending in entire 2000 campaign; Pres Bush's closing advertising pitch is similar to his opening one: world is dangerous place and nation's safety cannot be trusted to liberal like Sen John Kerry; Kerry's closing argument is result of several-month search for clean line of attack: Bush has made mess of Iraq, has not done enough to help middle class find jobs and afford health care, and it is time for 'fresh start'; Kerry's media strategists say they planned for last-minute advertising push months ago, forgoing any advertising in Aug so they could afford to advertise heavily now; say that in 2000, Al Gore's depleted war chest left him vulnerable in final days to Bush, who out-advertised him by some 30 percent; charts showing issues addressed in various ads; maps showing where ads are being placed (L)
docs.snippet: The campaign is coming to a close in an epic cacophony of advertisements striking notes of hope and fear, patriotism and betrayal.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER and JIM RUTENBERG; David M. Halbfinger reported from Tampa for this article, and Jim Rutenberg from Philadelphia. Richard W. Stevenson contributed reporting from Miami, and Glen Justice from Washington
